quiz.name: Module 11: Yield-Based Bond Duration Measures and Properties
quiz.subtopic: Module 11: Yield-Based Bond Duration Measures and Properties

entry.title: ITEM_2019B-FI-07CXM
entry.itemBody: Modified duration is the most appropriate measure of interest rate risk for which of the following securities?

answerFeedback.02e8c4e6-869f-437b-9301-cc29930a2fcb: Incorrect because a callable bond does not have a well-defined internal rate of return (yield-to-maturity). Therefore, yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, do not apply; effective duration is the appropriate duration measure.
answerFeedback.46477edd-84a4-45c6-8e14-7d15b32621df: Correct because modified duration can be used to measure the interest rate risk of a non-complex bond such as a US Treasury bond, while effective duration is essential to the measurement of the interest rate risk of a complex bond, such as a bond that contains an embedded call option.
answerFeedback.64f623eb-5630-4a8b-beda-35e3a1df77c9: Incorrect because another fixed-income security for which yield duration statistics, such as modified and Macaulay durations, are not relevant is a mortgage-backed bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06226
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three option-free bonds, each trading at a premium:

 

Coupon

 Yield To Maturity Time to Maturity
Bond 1 4% 4% 10 years
Bond 2 4% 5% 11 years
Bond 3 5% 5%

9 years

All else being equal, the bond with the lowest Macaulay duration is most likely:

answerFeedback.6bb87499-fcad-4110-be0d-dc02ffd2b76f: Correct because the Macaulay and modified duration statistics for a fixed-rate bond depend primarily on the coupon rate, yield-to-maturity, and time-to-maturity. A higher coupon rate or a higher yield-to-maturity reduces the duration measures. A longer time-to-maturity usually leads to a higher duration. It always does so for a bond priced at a premium or at par value. In this case, Bond 3 has a higher coupon, the same or higher yield-to-maturity, and the shortest time to maturity. It therefore has the lowest Macaulay duration.
answerFeedback.94edbe5b-1d55-4903-8d24-92158cb7c16b: Incorrect because the Macaulay and modified duration statistics for a fixed-rate bond depend primarily on the coupon rate, yield-to-maturity, and time-to-maturity. A higher coupon rate or a higher yield-to-maturity reduces the duration measures. A longer time-to-maturity usually leads to a higher duration. It always does so for a bond priced at a premium or at par value. Bond 1 has a lower coupon than Bond 3, a lower yield-to-maturity, and a longer maturity. The Macaulay duration of Bond 1 is therefore greater than that of Bond 3.
answerFeedback.f56e8422-2da8-43a9-9a34-08057f2992d4: Incorrect because the Macaulay and modified duration statistics for a fixed-rate bond depend primarily on the coupon rate, yield-to-maturity, and time-to-maturity. A higher coupon rate or a higher yield-to-maturity reduces the duration measures. A longer time-to-maturity usually leads to a higher duration. It always does so for a bond priced at a premium or at par value. Bond 2 has a lower coupon than Bond 3, the same yield-to-maturity, and a longer maturity. The Macaulay duration of Bond 2 is therefore greater than that of Bond 3.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Georgiou-10
entry.itemBody: For an option-free fixed-rate bond trading at a premium, as the coupon payment date approaches, Macaulay duration most likely:

answerFeedback.29bb8998-5ba8-45e3-8070-e5aa2f73b385: Correct because as time passes during the coupon period (moving from right to left in the diagram), the Macaulay duration declines smoothly and then jumps upward after the coupon is paid. The usual pattern is that longer times-to-maturity correspond to higher Macaulay duration statistics. This pattern always holds for bonds trading at par value or at a premium above par. Conversely, a shorter time to maturity corresponds to a lower Macaulay duration during the coupon period.
answerFeedback.d0c386e7-cf0e-4cee-8c7c-bead08d1b85e: Incorrect because if the bond is priced at a discount [not at a premium], a longer time-to-maturity might lead to a lower duration. This situation only occurs if the coupon rate is low (but not zero) relative to the yield and the time-to-maturity is long. Conversely, only for special cases of discount bonds, a shorter time to maturity might lead to a higher duration statistic.
answerFeedback.e1a41ec1-99c2-4b87-a3b6-03217c8200bd: Incorrect because the usual pattern is that longer times-to-maturity correspond to higher Macaulay duration statistics. This pattern always holds for bonds trading at par value or at a premium above par. Macaulay duration statistic stays constant if the bond is a perpetuity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03754
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Annual modified duration 5.2
Clean price $90
Accrued interest $5
Par value $100

If yield-to-maturity decreases by 10 basis points, the change in price for this bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.16cf68cb-7a73-4730-ba2f-9130815a4eb7:
Correct because the money duration of a bond is a measure of the price change in units of the currency in which the bond is denominated:

 MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull and, ΔPVFull ≈ –MoneyDur × ΔYield 

where

MoneyDur = money duration,

AnnModDur = annual modified duration,

PVFull = full price of bond = PVFlat + AI

and ΔPVFull = change in full price. (p. 409)

Therefore, ΔPVFull ≈ —(5.2 ×( 90 + 5)) × — 0.001 = 0.494 ≈ 0.49.
answerFeedback.77fe5502-a327-47bb-84bb-a268145e0627: Incorrect because the par value is used. ΔPVFull ≠ — (5.2 × 100) × — 0.001 = 0.52.
answerFeedback.f4b86921-55d6-4538-84f4-582b532fd441: Incorrect because the clean price is used: ΔPVFull ≠ — (5.2 × 90) × — 0.001 = 0.468 ≈ 0.47.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05224
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about the price of a semiannual-pay bond at various yield levels:

Yield-to-Maturity Full Price
2.9% 101.25
3.0% 100.00
3.1%   98.90

If the bond is currently priced at par, the approximate modified duration is closest to:

answerFeedback.16ad8b55-48b6-478d-afc4-1cc4dc8b6d5f: Incorrect because the candidate uses only the increase in price in the numerator: (101.25 – 100.00)/(2 × 0.001 × 100.00) = 6.25, or 6.3.
answerFeedback.9c82422f-d982-4d9c-ac60-ff0c3a13cd3f:
Correct because ApproxModDur = P V - -   P V + 2 × ∆ Yield × P V 0 ; where: PV0 = full price at current yield to maturity; PV+ = present value when the yield to maturity is increased; PV− = full price when the yield to maturity is decreased; ∆Yield = change in yield to maturity.

ApproxModDur=(101.25-98.90)(2×0.001×100.00)=11.75.
answerFeedback.d23e5076-0adc-4a49-aab1-1f345657ff35: Incorrect because the candidate uses the range of yields, e.g., 3.1 – 2.9, in the denominator: (101.25 – 98.90)/(2 × 0.002 × 100.00) = 5.875, or 5.9.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04184
entry.itemBody: The duration of an option-free bond is 10.21. If the current price of the bond is 121.355, the price value of a basis point (PVBP) is closest to:

answerFeedback.0a7110c9-459b-4471-b0f3-e17fbe8b6eb3: Incorrect because the PVBP cannot be a negative value because bond duration is derived by discounting bond cash flows.
answerFeedback.135fedf2-df9d-43c6-b152-7c25cbdf3b96: Incorrect because 0.1021 is the percentage price change for a 1 bp change in rates, not a dollar amount.
answerFeedback.dcb051ca-4a12-41dc-81d8-c07da492285b:
Correct because price value of a basis point (the absolute value of the change in the price of a bond for a 1-basis-point change in yield) is related to duration, the approximate percentage price change for a 100 bp change in rates. It follows that the approximate percentage price change for a 1 bp change in rates can be determined:

= duration × (0.0001) × 100

= (10.21) (0.0001) (100)

= 0.1021%, then

the current price × the % price change = 121.355 × 0.1021% = $0.1239.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08969
entry.itemBody: For a non-callable perpetual bond with a constant yield to maturity, the Macaulay duration is:

answerFeedback.635e3b76-9cbe-4de9-b329-b6b6c38bd47f: Incorrect because the Macaulay duration decreases smoothly as t goes from t = 0 to t = T, which creates a “saw-tooth” pattern. As time passes during the coupon period, the Macaulay duration declines smoothly and then jumps upward after the coupon is paid. As per the justification of the correct answer, the Macaulay duration of a non-callable perpetual bond is a function of its yield, and it is graphically represented as a horizontal line.
answerFeedback.6e168893-bd34-41e8-b933-30f83f6b6277: Correct because a perpetuity or perpetual bond is a bond that does not mature. There is no principal to redeem. The investor receives a fixed coupon payment forever, unless the bond is callable. Non-callable perpetuities have an interesting Macaulay duration: MacDur = (1 + r)/r as N approaches infinity, where r represents yield to maturity. The Macaulay duration of a non-callable perpetual bond is a function of its yield only.
answerFeedback.abe91cde-d9ee-42da-baa1-73dd3e1fd664: Incorrect because a perpetuity or perpetual bond is a bond that does not mature. Therefore, there is no time-to-maturity. On the other hand, the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond is its time-to-maturity.

choices.itemBody: A. equal to the bond's time to maturity.
C. calculated as (1 + yield to maturity) / yield to maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06080
entry.itemBody: The sensitivity of a bond's price to benchmark interest rates best defines:

answerFeedback.07bfe448-8cb3-498c-a418-e26c3455fc14: Correct because duration is a quantitative measure of interest rate risk. There are several duration measures, including those that measure a bond’s price sensitivity to changes in its own yield-to-maturity and assume underlying cash flows are certain (yield duration) and those that measure changes in a benchmark yield curve, with less certain underlying cash flows (curve duration).
answerFeedback.c01810d4-e696-4e1c-a664-86bede9ec4a2: Incorrect because duration is a quantitative measure of interest rate risk. There are several duration measures, including those that measure a bond’s price sensitivity to changes in its own yield-to-maturity and assume underlying cash flows are certain (yield duration) and those that measure changes in a benchmark yield curve, with less certain underlying cash flows (curve duration).
answerFeedback.d9fc6872-ffb9-43d1-b5a8-5cee7dfb7a78: Incorrect because duration is a quantitative measure of interest rate risk. There are several duration measures, including those that measure a bond’s price sensitivity to changes in its own yield-to-maturity and assume underlying cash flows are certain (yield duration) and those that measure changes in a benchmark yield curve, with less certain underlying cash flows (curve duration). Macaulay duration, modified duration, money duration, and the price value of a basis point (PVBP) are yield duration measures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02018
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

 

Price if interest rates fall 75 basis points 106.32
Price if interest rates rise 75 basis points 105.45

 

If the current price of the bond is 105.90, the effective duration is closest to:

answerFeedback.59798b0e-15be-4e4d-8ea8-aeff12aa329f:
Incorrect because it omits the 2 in the denominator:

(106.32 – 105.45)/(105.9)0.0075 = 1.095, rounded to 1.1.
answerFeedback.6006e61c-bfde-4fb7-a1fd-024030260f48:
Incorrect because 100bp (0.01) is used in the denominator rather than 0.0075:

(106.32 – 105.45)/2(105.9)0.01 = 0.4108, rounded to 0.41.

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q6

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The Macaulay, modified, and money duration measures, as well as the price value of a basis point, are all types of yield duration. The curve duration is not classified as a type of yield duration.

entry.itemBody: True or false: Curve duration is a type of yield duration.

entry.body:
A portfolio manager is assessing the interest rate risk of three bonds as she considers making an investment of USD50 million. All three bonds are issued on 1 June 2026 and mature on 1 June 2030, and they have the following characteristics:

Characteristic Bond One Bond Two Bond Three
Coupon (semiannual) 7% 3% 5%
Yield-to-maturity 3% 7% 5%
entry.title: Vignette
CFA2441-R-s04-Q7

feedback.neutral:
B is correct.

Period Time to receipt Cash flow Present value Weight Time to receipt × weight
1 1.0000 3.5 3.44828 0.02999 0.02999
2 2.0000 3.5 3.39732 0.02955 0.05910
3 3.0000 3.5 3.34711 0.02911 0.08734
4 4.0000 3.5 3.29764 0.02868 0.11473
5 5.0000 3.5 3.24891 0.02826 0.14129
6 6.0000 3.5 3.20090 0.02784 0.16704
7 7.0000 3.5 3.15359 0.02743 0.19200
8 8.0000 103.5 91.87810 0.79914 6.39308
114.97185 1.00000 7.18458
Annualized Macaulay duration 3.59229

entry.itemBody: The Macaulay duration, in years, for Bond One is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q8

feedback.neutral:
B is correct.

Period Time to receipt Cash flow Present value Weight Time to receipt × weight
1 1.0000 1.5 1.44928 0.01680 0.01680
2 2.0000 1.5 1.40027 0.01623 0.03247
3 3.0000 1.5 1.35291 0.01569 0.04706
4 4.0000 1.5 1.30716 0.01516 0.06062
5 5.0000 1.5 1.26296 0.01464 0.07321
6 6.0000 1.5 1.22025 0.01415 0.08488
7 7.0000 1.5 1.17899 0.01367 0.09568
8 8.0000 101.5 77.08027 0.89366 7.14930
86.25209 1.00000 7.56003
Annualized Macaulay duration 3.780016
Modified duration 3.652190

entry.itemBody: The modified duration for Bond Two is closest to:

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q9

feedback.neutral:
A is correct. No calculation is necessary, as we know that a five-year zero-coupon bond has a Macaulay duration of 5, which is greater than that of a coupon bond like Bond three. Since they have the same yields, the bond’s modified durations will have the same relationship as their Macaulay duration.

Alternatively, we can calculate Bond Three’s modified duration of 3.585:

Period Time to receipt Cash flow Present value Weight Time to receipt × weight
1 1.0000 2.5 2.43902 0.02439 0.02439
2 2.0000 2.5 2.37954 0.02380 0.04759
3 3.0000 2.5 2.32150 0.02321 0.06964
4 4.0000 2.5 2.26488 0.02265 0.09060
5 5.0000 2.5 2.20964 0.02210 0.11048
6 6.0000 2.5 2.15574 0.02156 0.12934
7 7.0000 2.5 2.10316 0.02103 0.14722
8 8.0000 102.5 84.12652 0.84127 6.73012
100.00000 1.00000 7.34939
Annualized Macaulay duration 3.6747
Modified duration 3.5851

The zero-coupon’s modified duration is 5/(1 + 0.05) = 4.7619.

entry.itemBody: Relative to a five-year zero-coupon bond priced to yield 5%, Bond Three has a modified duration that is best described as:

choices.itemBody: A. lower than the zero-coupon bond’s modified duration.
B. the same as the zero-coupon bond’s modified duration.
C. greater than the zero-coupon bond’s modified duration.

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q10

feedback.neutral:
B is correct.

Bond One Bond Two Bond Three
Full price (percent of par) 114.972 86.252 100.000
Modified duration 3.539 3.652 3.585
Investment (in USD millions) 50 50 50
Money duration 176.960 182.609 179.253
Change in value (in USD millions) –1.770 –1.826 –1.793

entry.itemBody: If the yields-to-maturity for all three bonds were to increase by 100 bps, which bond has the greatest anticipated decrease in price?

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q11

feedback.neutral:
A is correct.

Bond One Bond Two Bond Three
Price 114.972 86.252 100.000
Price + 1 bp 114.931 86.221 99.964
Price – 1 bp 115.013 86.284 100.036
PVBP 0.04069 0.03150 0.03585

entry.itemBody: Which bond has the highest price value of a basis point?

entry.title: CFA2441-R-s04-Q12

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The Macaulay duration for Bond Three is 3.6747. The Macaulay duration for Bond Four is 0.5 because there is exposure to interest rate changes for one-half of the coupon period.

entry.itemBody: The portfolio manager is interested in comparing the interest rate risk of Bond Three to that of Bond Four, a floating-rate note that resets every six months. On 1 June 2026, both bonds were priced to yield 5%. If the yield changes from 5% to 5.25% halfway through the first coupon period, which bond has the greater Macaulay duration?

choices.itemBody: C. Neither: The Macaulay duration is the same for both bonds.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607118
entry.itemBody: Which of these definitions of duration is most relevant to a bond investor? A bond’s duration is its:

answerFeedback.d3b94a44-9812-43f0-9fd3-489431927410: Incorrect because while it’s true that duration is the weighted-average maturity or half-life for some bonds, for others the duration has nothing to do with maturity (e.g., an interest only strip security.)
answerFeedback.d57e5603-c17f-4b7e-9c16-fa913d68e600: Correct. Bond investors are concerned about interest rate risk, and duration is a good measure of interest rate risk.
answerFeedback.f80d7156-c006-45d6-9466-8a99a488b9a1: Incorrect because while duration was first measured using the calculus, referring to it in this way is confusing for investors who are unfamiliar with calculus or might confuse it with a derivative security.

choices.itemBody: C. first derivative of value with respect to its yield.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516052
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements regarding Macaulay duration is correct?

answerFeedback.1bef9eea-e3ae-41dc-a636-253072c04a8c: Incorrect because for the same time to maturity and yield to maturity, the Macaulay duration is higher (not lower) for a zero-coupon bond than for a low-coupon bond trading at a discount.
answerFeedback.9213ee83-6409-4027-904a-3e9e5ff80d58: Incorrect because for the same time to maturity and yield to maturity, the Macaulay duration is higher (not lower) for a low-coupon bond trading at a discount than for a high-coupon bond trading at a premium.
answerFeedback.c0209ae4-b05b-4db1-bd45-ff5588c9daf2: Correct because generally, the Macaulay duration statistic increases with a bond’s time to maturity. This pattern always holds for bonds trading at par value or at a premium but does not always hold for discount bonds. In the case of discount bonds, for a given coupon rate, a longer-term discount bond can have a lower Macaulay duration than a shorter-term discount bond. This situation typically occurs when the number of periods remaining in the bond’s life is large and the coupon rate is below the yield to maturity.

choices.itemBody: A. For a given coupon rate, Macaulay duration can be lower for a long-term discount bond than for a short-term discount bond.
B. For a given time to maturity and yield to maturity, Macaulay duration is lower for a zero-coupon bond than for a low-coupon bond trading at a discount.
C. For a given time to maturity and yield to maturity, Macaulay duration is lower for a low-coupon bond trading at a discount than for a high-coupon bond trading at a premium.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516056
entry.itemBody:
Consider the following information relating to a corporate bond:
Full price of bond (PVFull) $100,367,242
Modified duration (AnnModDur) 8.124 years
Accrued interest $303,218

The money duration of the corporate bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.003733de-2bf2-4427-a477-4d165111d5c8:
Correct. The money duration of the corporate bond is equal to $815,383,474.

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull

 = 8.124 × $100,367,242

 = $815,383,474
answerFeedback.09a78b67-e13f-4f47-afd0-36fd25b22fcf:
Incorrect because the full price of the bond (PVFull) includes accrued interest. The calculation of money duration should include accrued interest. However, accrued interest is incorrectly subtracted from the full price of the bond here:

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × [PVFull – Accrued interest]

 = 8.124 × [$100,367,242 – $303,218]

 = $812,920,131
answerFeedback.3a5e3a04-07a2-403b-824d-63ad8b50d041:
Incorrect because the full price of the bond (PVFull) already includes accrued interest. Accrued interest was incorrectly added to the full price of the bond here:

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × [PVFull + Accrued interest]

 = 8.124 × [$100,367,242 + $303,218]

 = $817,846,817

entry.title: ITEM_20190531014
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information on a bond:
Price 85.4734
Payment frequency Annual
Time to maturity 5 years
Coupon 4%
Macaulay duration 4.5947

Modified duration is closest to:

answerFeedback.aca10729-4bd2-42c5-b06d-0a642011f32b: Incorrect. It is the result of incorrectly multiplying Macaulay duration by 1 plus the coupon rate.
answerFeedback.b0572b36-9775-4437-aeb6-d88ef3d2729b: Incorrect. It is the result of incorrectly dividing Macaulay duration by the coupon rate, rather than YTM.
answerFeedback.d65acd73-a059-4941-a84e-001dfd17ca47:
Correct. Modified duration is Macaulay duration divided by 1 plus yield per period. Macaulay duration is provided in the table, so YTM is calculated as follows:

N = 5.

PV = 85.4734.

PMT = –4.

FV = –100.

CPT I/Y = 7.6%.

ModDur = 4.5947 1.076 =4.2702

entry.title: ITEM_20190531022
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information for a bond:
Position (par value) $100,000,000
Flat price 97.1251
Accrued interest 0.4392
Macaulay duration 8.586
Annual modified duration 8.450

The money duration of the bond position is closest to:

answerFeedback.4b10d1fb-c56d-4ef3-b34b-50f39e36d454:
Correct. Money duration is calculated as the annual modified duration times the full price of the bond including accrued interest:

MoneyDur = AnnModDur × PVFull.

The full price of the bond is 97.5643 (97.1251 + 0.4392) per 100 of par, or $97,564,300. Therefore, the money duration of this bond position is $824,418,335 (97,564,300 × 8.45).
answerFeedback.4c5769e0-4061-44ed-a606-f5993feae6a4:
Incorrect. It is the result if the full price of the bond is incorrectly multiplied by Macaulay duration:

$837,687,080 ≈ (97,564,300 × 8.586).
answerFeedback.951a056b-0ac7-4d67-a2af-a446953dd271: Incorrect. It is the result of neglecting to incorporate accrued interest when pricing the bond position and erroneously multiplying by Macaulay duration.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Georgiou-14
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Clean price (per 100 of par value) 114.75
Annual modified duration 4.8250
Macaulay duration (years) 4.9469
Accrued interest (per 100 of par value) 1.6250

The bond's money duration (per 100 of par value) is closest to:

answerFeedback.367a3b6f-ef8e-4210-a208-c2b391fc9025:
Correct because the money duration equals the product of modified duration and full price.

Full price = Clean price + Accrued interest = 114.75 + 1.625 = 116.375;

Money duration = Modified duration × Full Price = 116.375 × 4.8250 = 561.5094 ≈ 561.51.

Modified duration is a measure of the percentage price change of a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity. A related statistic is money duration. The money duration of a bond is a measure of the price change in units of the currency in which the bond is denominated. The money duration can be stated per 100 of par value or in terms of the actual position size of the bond in the portfolio. In the United States, money duration is commonly called 'dollar duration.' Money duration (MoneyDur) is calculated as the annual modified duration times the full price (PVFull) of the bond, including accrued interest.
answerFeedback.4bc7f832-c2a2-43c0-b0bc-b7da247293c2:
Incorrect because it multiplies the modified duration with the clean price instead of the full price.

4.8250 × 114.75 = 553.6688 ≈ 553.67.
answerFeedback.a72912de-b06b-4cdb-806b-3d37755c5175:
Incorrect because it multiplies the full price with the Macaulay duration instead of the modified duration. 

Full price = Clean price + Accrued interest = 114.75 + 1.625 = 116.375;

Macaulay duration × Full price = 4.9469 × 116.375 = 575.6955 ≈ 575.70.

entry.title: ITEM_2019BFI07EKH
entry.itemBody: The percentage price change for a bond, given a change in its yield to maturity, is best estimated by:

answerFeedback.45f5396c-0d9d-4e31-bc40-183dcf8daa91: Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a weighted average of the time to receipt of the bond’s promised payments, where the weights are the shares of the full price that correspond to each of the bond’s promised future payments.
answerFeedback.471a4616-1243-4d16-8746-f78e56f54966: Incorrect because the effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond’s price to a change in a benchmark yield curve, not to a change in the bond’s yield to maturity.
answerFeedback.b99fb0e2-1666-414a-8628-e5ff10dec077: Correct because modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond’s own yield-to-maturity.  Modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00439
entry.itemBody:
An investor determines the following information about the price sensitivity of an option-free bond:

Rate Change Price
75 basis point increase 104.0
75 basis point decrease 108.5

If the current price is 106, the duration of this bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.13ade29c-4406-415f-a58a-0fb84e2ffb47:
Incorrect because it uses par value instead of market value in the denominator.

Duration ≠ 108.5 – 104

2 × 100 × 0.0075 ≠ 3.0
answerFeedback.a42f945a-4e03-4756-ac13-7f243ed0d973:
Incorrect because it uses 100 bps instead of 75bps in the denominator.

Duration ≠ 108.5 – 104

2 × 106 × 0.0100 ≠ 2.12, or 2.1
answerFeedback.c98d6be3-fb00-4105-bcb8-0284b89aa3af:
Correct because the following formula estimates the approximate percentage price change for a 100 basis point change in yield (duration) is:

Duration = Price if yield declines – Price if yield rises

2 × (initial price) × (change in yield in decimal format)

= 108.5 – 104

2 × 106 × 0.0075

= 4.5

1.59

= 2.83, or 2.8

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04633
entry.itemBody: The price value of a basis point (PVBP) for a bond with a full price of 103.50 and a modified duration of 6.2 is closest to:

answerFeedback.4efd4788-b127-457f-93b2-505bf9bc3253: Incorrect because it represents a 1 percent change in rates (100 bp), not 1 bp: −6.2 × 0.01 = 0.062 and PVBP ≠ 0.062 × 103.50 = 6.417, rounded to 6.42.
answerFeedback.7c49a504-041c-43b1-abb6-93ce277b3953: Incorrect because it represents a 10 bp change in rates, not 1 bp: −6.2 × 0.001 = 0.0062 and PVBP ≠ 0.0062 × 103.50 = 0.6417, rounded to 0.642.
answerFeedback.e66028df-f335-4e82-bd29-0bdd265e002f:
Correct because modified duration provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity:

%ΔPVFull ≈ −AnnModDur × ΔYield.

Also, another version of money duration is the price value of a basis point (PVBP) for the bond. The PVBP is an estimate of the change in the full price given a 1 bp change in the yield-to-maturity. 

Here: −6.2 × 0.0001 = 0.00062 and PVBP = 0.00062 × 103.50 = 0.06417, rounded to 0.0642.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Larrabee-01
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the following price-yield relationship for an option-free bond:

Price per 100 of Par Value Yield to Maturity
100.95 7.45%
101.80 6.75%
103.40 6.05%

If the bond trades at 101.80 per 100 of par value, its approximate modified duration is closest to:

answerFeedback.057cfeab-c5fd-46ff-9785-b8338dd00d30:
Correct because the approximate modified duration of a bond is calculated as follows:

ApproxModDur = ((PV–) – (PV+)) / (2 × (ΔYield) × PV0) = (103.40 – 100.95) / (2 × 0.0070 × 101.80) = 2.45 / 1.4252 = 1.7191 ≈ 1.72.
answerFeedback.3fa9ca93-c627-4322-8e9f-8c3af985c2d9:
Incorrect because the approximate modified duration of a bond is calculated as follows:

ApproxModDur = ((PV–) – (PV+)) / (2 × (ΔYield) × PV0). However, in this case, the higher yield/lower price is omitted from the calculation and the multiplication by 2 in the denominator is omitted as well: = (103.40 – 101.80)/(101.80(6.75% – 6.05%)) = 2.2453 = 2.25.
answerFeedback.ccce7c7a-58b5-4e03-8d6e-1bef3bbe1386:
Incorrect because the approximate modified duration of a bond is calculated as follows:

ApproxModDur = ((PV–) – (PV+)) / (2 × (ΔYield) × PV0). However, in this case, the number 2 is omitted from the denominator: = (103.40 – 100.95) / (0.0070 × 101.80) = 2.45 / 0.7126 = 3.4381 ≈ 3.44.
